awd_titl_txt: CRII: CPS: A Bi-Trust Framework for Collaboration-Quality Improvement in Human-Robot Collaborative Contexts
awd_abstract_narration:
Collaborative robots have been widely employed to assist humans in an increasing number of areas. Just as human-human collaboration, the trust in human-robot teams has a property of bidirectional. However, few studies have been conducted on both human-trusting-robot issue and robot-trusting-human issue in a unified framework for human-robot collaboration. The project addresses this challenge by developing a new systematic Bi-Trust framework to integrate humans’ trust in robots and robots’ trust in humans into the human-robot collaboration process. With the established Bi-Trust framework, a trust-level-based computational collaboration model is created to optimize and plan robot actions. The proposed approaches will reduce uncertain failures and improve the collaboration-quality of human-robot shared tasks.

The goal of this project is to develop a systematic Bi-Trust framework for human-robot teams and create new computational models of trust dynamics and trust-level-based collaboration in order to enhance the human-robot partnership. The proposed research activities include: (1) investigating the factors that affect humans’ trust in robots and analyzing humans’ trust using multimodal physical and physiological data; (2) developing a new Bi-Trust framework entailing computational human-trusting-robot model and robot-trusting-human model for human-robot teams and establishing a computational human-robot collaboration model via the trust-local-maximum method; and (3) applying the Bi-Trust framework in real-world human-robot collaborative contexts and assessing its effectiveness. The findings of this project will improve the collaboration-quality for human-robot teams in collaborative contexts such as the new generation of smart manufacturing and potentially benefit the national economic growth by fostering increasing robotics and AI workforce.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This CRII project focuses on developing a systematic bi-trust framework including a robot-human trust model and a human-robot trust model for human-robot teams and applying them in trust-based human-robot collaborative contexts to improve collaboration-quality. The outcomes of this project were shared with both academia and industry through multiple peer-reviewed journal and conference publications, talks and poster presentations by the PI and his team members, seminars and workshops, faculty panels, industry expos, publicly available resources, interactive STEM showcases and tours, media attention featuring this research, and education materials.

The project has led to advanced understandings and new findings on the trust issue in the human-robot collaborative process. The major contributions included the development of (1) a multimodal human-robot trust database with 100 user studies in human-robot collaborative contexts for the field; (2) new characterization approaches for human trust in robots through multimodal physical and physiological biometrics in human-robot partnerships; (3) a human-robot trust model that was effectively used to reveal the correlation between robot performance factors and humans' trust levels and to parameterize humans' trust in robots in real-world human-robot collaborative tasks; (4) a robot-human trust model by which the robot can accurately perceive its trust in the human in real-time during the human-robot collaboration; and (5) a trust-based human-robot collaboration model enabling the robot to actively accommodate and assist its human partner in shared tasks. As human-centered technologies and applications have increasingly impacted everyone everywhere across the world, this project provided original insights for advancing the human factors research in human-robot/machine/AI interaction.

This CRII project resulted in 11 publications in the fields of robotics, automation, artificial intelligence, smart manufacturing, intelligent systems, and data science. The research outcomes led to multiple awards and recognitions including (1) the IEEE STEM Champion Award; (2) the New Jersey Space Grant Consortium Fellowship; (3) the Second Place Best Paper Award at the IEEE MIT URTC Conference; (4) five media reports highlighting the research and educational activities and products enabled by this project; and (5) keynote speech/invited talks at IEEE conferences and seminars.

The project created various training opportunities. It has provided research training for four graduate and four undergraduate students (62.5% of them are from underrepresented groups), which highly widened their career pipelines. This project has upgraded and enriched the PI's robotics courses for both graduate and undergraduate students. New teaching modules on robotics and hands-on projects were developed in the PI's robotics courses that have benefited 241 students (a large portion are female students and underrepresented minorities). During the project period, the PI founded a university-level club Montclair Robotics Club to provide both STEM and non-STEM students with the necessary tools and knowledge to explore the field of robotics and AI. The research outcomes have helped the PI develop a pre-college summer program, establish the IEEE Montclair Student Branch, and organize 19 robotics talks, seminars, workshops, showcases, and open houses that covered over 536 participants including faculty members, college students, parents, teachers, K-12 students, and community partners. These academic opportunities and events have attracted a large number of women and minorities to the STEM field, broadening the participation of groups traditionally underrepresented in CISE.
